citeinfo.title: Monthly Inflows to the Surface Water Network for the Central Valley Hydrologic Model Version 2 (CVHM2)
Groundwater Sustainability and Land Subsidence in California’s Central Valley

descript.abstract: This digital dataset contains the monthly inflows to the surface water network in the updated Central Valley Hydrologic Model (CVHM2) for water years 1922-2019. The surface water inflows are simulated through the Streamflow Routing Package (SFR2) using 65 inflows locations, 271 stream segments that represent 4043 stream reaches, and 13 bifurcations that comprise the stream network. The bifurcations simulate the bypass canals that are used for flood control by routing water between two stream reach locations within the stream network. This dataset includes the inflow and bifurcation locations and monthly magnitude.
descript.purpose: The surface water inflow and bifurcation dataset were used as input the Streamflow Routing Package (SFR2) of the CVHM2 to simulate surface water flow in the CVHM2.
descript.supplinf: This data release has been modified from its original version. See “CVHM2_SurfaceWater_versionhistory.txt” in the attached files section on the parent page for this data release for more detail (https://doi.org/10.5066/P9ICSZWF).

place.placekt: U.S. Board of Geographic Names (BGN) and Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations. It is requested that the suggested citation for this USGS data release be included in any publications that reference or utilize these data.
idinfo.datacred: Spatial datasets supporting the Central Valley Groundwater Availability project were developed primarily by the U.S. Geological Survey's (USGS) Groundwater Resources Program. This program is conducting large-scale multidisciplinary regional studies of groundwater availability. The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation is supporting the updating of the Central Valley datasets and their documentation and release.

attracc.attraccr: Data have been checked to ensure the accuracy of the data. If any errors are detected, please notify the originating office. The U.S. Geological Survey strongly recommends that careful attention be paid to the metadata file associated with these data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and (or) contained herein. Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey would be appreciated in products derived from these data. Any use of trade, product, or firm names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. Although this Federal Geographic Data Committee-compliant metadata file is intended to document the dataset in nonproprietary form, as well as in ArcGIS format, this metadata file may include some ArcGIS-specific terminology.

dataqual.logic: Tabular, non-spatial dataset. Categories were determined by the dataset originator, who transcribed them into this table.
dataqual.complete: The measurements in this dataset are computer-generated and are used as input in the Central Valley Hydrologic Model. The dataset is complete and is not anticipated to change.

citeinfo.origin: California Department of Water Resources (CA DWR)
citeinfo.title: The California Hydroclimate Report Water Year 2019

citeinfo.title: One-Water Hydrologic Flow Model: A MODFLOW based conjunctive-use simulation software

procstep.procdesc: Inflow data was downloaded from the National Water Information System (USGS, 2019) at gage sites located along the stream network and were aggregated to monthly volumes in cubic meters per day for water years 1922- 2019. The tabulated inflows were used as input to the Streamflow Routing Package (SFR2) to simulate the surface water network in the CVHM2.

Monthly reservoir releases were downloaded from the California Data Exchange Center at locations along the stream network for water years 1922- 2019 (CA DWR, 2015). The tabulated reservoir releases were used as inflows to the Streamflow Routing Package (SFR2) to simulate the surface water network in the CVHM2.

Monthly inflow data was gathered from the Fine Grid California Central Valley Groundwater-Surface Water Simulation Model (C2VSimFG Version 1.0; Hatch, 2021) for water years 1922 - 2015. The data was tabulated and used as input to the Streamflow Routing Package (SFR2) to simulate flow in the CVHM2.

Inflows for site identifiers CACH_390, CACH_Low, FKWI_024, FKWT_011, FKWK_421, CVCK_004, FKCK_004, LPAN_999, LBAN_999, DMC, Cal_Aq, Zapato were extended for water years 2016 - 2019 using historical values based on water year designations defined by the Department of Water Resources annual Hydroclimate Report. Water year type designations were matched with similar historical designations for the San Joaquin and Sacramento Valley Regions and used as inflows to extend the model through water year 2019. The water year types were either "wet", "normal", "above normal", "below normal", "critically dry", or "dry" as defined by the California Hydroclimate Report (CA DWR, 2019).

Ten of the SFR bifurcations were gathered from the 1.0 version of the Fine Grid California Central Valley Groundwater-Surface Water Simulation Model (C2VSimFG Version 1.0; Hatch, 2021) from bypass locations in the diversion file (C2VSimFG_Diversions.dat) for the water years 1922 - 2015. The bypass locations include Moulton, Colusa, Tisdale, Fremont, Sacramento Weir, Knights, Bypass #1, Bypass #2, Bypass #3, and KNGN. The Delta and Mariposa Bypasses were routed through SFR using a defined fraction of the available flow into segment (iprior = -2). The Chowchilla Bypass uses a constant value of 50 cubic feet per second (cfs).

The bifurcations were extended for water years 2016 - 2019 using historical values based on water year designations defined by the Department of Water Resources annual Hydroclimate Report. Water year type designations were matched with similar historical designations for the San Joaquin and Sacramento Valley Regions and used as inflows to extend the model through water year 2019. The water year types were either "wet", "normal", "above normal", "below normal", "critically dry", or "dry" as defined by the California Hydroclimate Report (CA DWR, 2019).
